current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To require the Secretary of the Treasury to mint coins in commemoration of the United States Coast
			 Guard.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
United States Coast Guard
			 Commemorative Coin Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: United States Coast Guard Commemorative Coin Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
was founded on August 4, 1790, as the Revenue Cutter Service
			 under
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Department of the Treasury

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
created
			 the

on January 28, 1915, by merging the Revenue Cutter Service
			 and
			 the United States Lifesaving Service, was moved to the
in 1967, and on February 25, 2003, became part of the

conducts a wide variety of missions to protect the public, the
			 environment, and
			 the United States economic and security interests in any maritime region,
			 including international waters and America’s coasts, ports, and inland
			 waterways.

text.#text:
Although the
			 smallest of the uniformed services, today the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
plays a broad and important role in homeland
			 security, law enforcement, search and rescue, marine environmental
			 pollution
			 response, and the maintenance of river, intra-coastal and offshore aids to
			 navigation (ATON).

text.#text: Every day, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is our Nation’s oldest seafaring military service, staying
			 true to
			 their motto, Semper Paratus or

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has an
			 estimated 42,300 men and women on active duty, who in 2012 responded to
			 nearly
			 20,000 search and rescue incidents saving over 3,500 lives and protecting
			 $77
			 million in property, removed 107 metric tons of cocaine and 56 metric tons
			 of
			 marijuana headed to the United States, and interdicted nearly 3,000
			 undocumented migrants on the high seas attempting to illegally enter the
			 United
			 States.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: states that

quote.#text:
The Commandant may establish a National
			 Coast Guard Museum, on lands which will be federally owned and
			 administered by
			 the Coast Guard, and are located in New London, Connecticut, at, or in
			 close
			 proximity to, the Coast Guard Academy

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, is
			 working with the

, the City of New London, the
			 State
			 of Connecticut, and a range of local, regional, and national stakeholders
			 to
			 develop, plan and raise capital for the National Coast Guard Museum, to be
			 located in New London, Connecticut.

text.#text:
The National Coast
			 Guard Museum Association, a nonprofit association dedicated to improve
			 public
			 understanding of the history, service and missions of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is the only military service without a national museum through
			 which to share its history and legacy with the American public.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (hereafter in this Act referred to as the

text.#text: The

quote.#tail: ) shall mint and issue the following coins:

text.#text: Not more than 100,000 $5 coins, which shall—

weigh 8.359
			 grams;

have a diameter of
			 0.850 inches; and

contain 90 percent
			 gold and 10 percent alloy.
Not more than 500,000 $1 coins, which shall—

weigh 26.73
			 grams;

have a diameter of
			 1.500 inches; and

contain 90 percent
			 silver and 10 percent copper.

Not more than 750,000 half dollar coins, which
			 shall—

weigh 11.34
			 grams;

have a diameter of
			 1.205 inches; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 5112(b) of
			 title 31,
			 United States Code

text.#text:
be minted to the
			 specifications for half dollar coins, contained in

The coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender, as
			 provided in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and

, all coins minted under this Act shall be considered to be
			 numismatic items.

text.#text: For purposes of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , and its role in securing our Nation since 1790.

text.#text:
The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be
			 emblematic of the traditions, history, and heritage of the

On each coin minted under this Act, there shall
			 be—

a designation of
			 the value of the coin;

an inscription of
			 the year

inscriptions of
			 the words

The
			 design for the coins minted under this Act shall—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the mission and goals of the National Coast Guard
			 Museum,
			 and the missions and goals of the National Coast Guard Museum
			 Foundation;

text.#text:
contain motifs that specifically honor the
			 American Coast Guardsman of both today and yesterday, in wartime and in
			 peace,
			 such designs to be consistent with the traditions and heritage of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, after
			 consultation with the

, the National Coast
			 Guard
			 Museum Foundation, and the
; and

text.#text: be selected by the
be reviewed by the

Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated
			 and proof qualities.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall be used to strike proof
			 quality coins, while at least 1 other such facility shall be used to
			 strike the
			 uncirculated quality coins.

text.#text:
For each of the 3 coins minted under this Act, at
			 least 1 facility of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may issue coins minted under this Act only
			 during the 1-year period beginning on January 1, 2017.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: at a price equal to the sum of—

text.#text: The coins issued under this Act shall be sold by the

the face value of
			 the coins;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: with respect to such coins; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: United States Coast Guard Commemorative Coin Act/s:7/ss:a

text.#text:
the surcharge
			 provided in

the cost of
			 designing and issuing the coins (including labor, materials, dies, use of
			 machinery, overhead expenses, marketing, and shipping).

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall make bulk sales of the coins issued
			 under this Act at a reasonable discount.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall accept prepaid orders for the coins
			 minted under this Act before the issuance of such coins.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall be at a
			 reasonable discount.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: United States Coast Guard Commemorative Coin Act/s:6/ss:c/p:1

text.#text:
Sale
			 prices with respect to prepaid orders under

All sales of coins minted under this Act shall include a
			 surcharge as follows:

A
			 surcharge of $35 per coin for the $5 coin.

A
			 surcharge of $10 per coin for the $1 coin.

A
			 surcharge of $5 per coin for the half dollar coin.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, all surcharges
			 received by
			 the

from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be
			 promptly
			 paid by the

to the National Coast Guard Museum Foundation to
			 help
			 finance the design, construction, operations, and maintenance of the
			 National
			 Coast Guard Museum.

text.#text:
Subject
